name: Þingeyrakirkja - Stone Church on Ancient Monastery Site
description: Þingeyrakirkja stands as one of Iceland's most historically significant churches, built of stone and consecrated in 1877 to replace old turf church on site that had hosted Þingeyrar, Iceland's first permanent Benedictine monastery from 1133 to 1551—this nearly 420-year monastic history represents longest-running and most influential monastery in Icelandic history, making Þingeyrar essential pilgrimage site for understanding medieval Iceland's religious, cultural, and educational development. Member of Parliament Ásgeir Einarsson (1809-1885) funded and oversaw the church's construction, a project that lasted 13 years and required extraordinary effort: stones used for construction were hauled over ice and snow on sleds from Nesbjörg located further west, demonstrating determination and community commitment necessary for major building projects in 19th-century Iceland where limited resources and harsh climate made monumental architecture rare achievement. The current stone church preserves and displays objects from the previous turf church, creating material continuity with earlier worship traditions while the substantial stone construction represents modernization and permanence that turf buildings could never achieve. The monastery that preceded the church earned enormous wealth and power during medieval period.
address: Þingeyrar, 531 Hvammstangi, Iceland (northwest Iceland, Húnaflói region)
